courses.feedback_evaluation: At the end of the course, students are reuqired to fill in the questionnaire to provide feedback on different aspects, including comments on the content and arrangememt of the College Assemblies/High Table Dinner.

courses.description: This course aims at helping new students to develop an understanding and appreciation of university education and to adapt to campus life. Origins, traditions and objectives of universities, and their relationships with individual and society will be introduced. Distinctions between adult learning and juvenile learning, high-school and university studies will be elaborated. Advice and effective social and study skills will be provided to facilitate smooth transition. The Founder’s Ideas and the WS (Woo Sing) Spirit will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College Year 1 students only
2. Not for students who have taken GEWS1012
courses.course_syllabus:
1. University Education

· The meaning of university education

A. Expectation on university study

• Brinkworth, R., McCann, B. Matthews, C., Nordstrom, K. (2009). First year expectations and experiences: Student and teacher perspectives. Higher Education, 58(2), 157-173.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: The Art of Leadership
courses.description:
A team is a group of two or more people who have a common objective or purpose with a commitment to collective and incremental improvement. Great teams, like great leaders, are made, not born. Two concepts, trust and commitment, are the glue that holds teams together. The objective of this course is to train the students to be a leader who can foster these two aspects of the team.

In this course, the students will learn the attributes of trust-building and commitment-building through lectures, workshops, and outdoor activities. The students will also participate in team projects designed by the College. By this chance, they will practise their knowledge and skills through thorough guidance by College supervisors.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Wo Sing College students only.
courses.component:
Debate
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
Workshop
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Explain the nature, purpose and structure of a team

• Equip with the individual attributes that contribute to success of teamwork
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Lectures: Introduction of leadership and teamwork

2) Workshops and outdoor activities: Trust-building and Commitment-building
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

2. Internal Course Review
courses.required_readings:
Characters of good leaders:

1) 露瑪・伯斯 (Bose, R)、路・佛斯特 (Faust, L.) (2012)。貧民窟裡的領導 : 德蕾莎修女的管理智慧 (Mother Teresa, CEO：unexpected principles for practical leadership) (朱道凱譯) (一版)。台北市 : 天下雜誌股份有限公司。
courses.recommended_readings:
Characters of good leaders:

1) 約翰．麥斯威爾 (Maxwell, J. C.) (2008)。360度全方位領導。台灣：英柏爾。

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: General History of China
courses.description: This course aims at introducing the main course of changes in Chinese history and the value of Chinese cultural heritage. Through lectures and discussions, it covers major issues in development of Chinese history. Examples of the topics include the origin of Chinese culture, milestones in dynastic history, intellectual thoughts and social structures. Field trip and tutorial help students to understand the relationship between Chinese history and Hong Kong development. After taking this course, students are expected to develop critical thinking and analysis skills in a historical context, and further interests in the learning of Chinese culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for History Majors.
3. Not for students who have taken UGEA2230.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

• acquire a general knowledge and understanding in Chinese history.
courses.course_syllabus:
第一章 引論：讀國史的信念

第二章 中國文化之起源
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

2. Internal Course Review

1. 錢穆：《國史大綱•引論》，臺北：國立編譯館，1984年，頁一至二九。
courses.recommended_readings:

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: China and The World
courses.description:
Napoleon Bonaparte once said of China: “China is a sleeping lion. Let her sleep, for when she wakes she will move the world.” Today, China has risen to become the second largest global economic power; and some experts even predicted that her economy is poised to overtake the US economy by year-2035. Is Napoleon’s prophecy going to come true?

China has remained an enigma to the rest of the world. Traditional China’s accomplishments towards medicine, painting, architecture, martial art music and dance had impressed the world and her inventions such as paper, gunpowder, compass, and printing had helped move Europe to the modern age.

This course aims to examine the evolvement of the Chinese civilization and factors affecting how China interacts with the rest of the world. It will also explore the extent and impacts of intercultural exchanges between China and the world. The course will also look at the role Hong Kong played in China’s interaction with foreign powers in the past and assess opportunities afforded Hong Kong in the implementation of the Chinese “One Belt, one Road” initiative.

In conclusion, the course will assess the swift rise of contemporary China, and the aftermaths brought by her rapid industrialization. The course will try to answer if China will fulfil Napoleon’s prophecy.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be be able to:

- Explain the artistic, philosophical and scientific inventions and discoveries made by the Chinese in historical as well as contemporary China and understand their impacts in history as well as in today’s world
courses.course_syllabus:
Part A. China and its culture

- Background information about China: its location, geography, languages spoken and factors leading to the rise of imperial China.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

2. Internal Course Review
courses.required_readings:
1. Ropp, Paul S. China in World History, Oxford University Press, 2010.

2. Temple, Robert. The Genius of China: 3000 Years of Science, Discovery and Invention, Inner Tradition. 2007.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Adshead, S.A.M. China in World History, MacMillan Press Ltd., 2000

2. Patricia Buckley Ebrey (ed.) Chinese Civilization: A Sourcebook, Second edition, Free Press, 1993.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Future of Food: Plant-based Living

meetings.location: Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R
Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R
Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R

courses.description: This course helps students to understand the major concepts, theories, debates and reflections related to plant-based lifestyle. Particular thematic issues such as global warming and pollution, food crisis, diet and health, animal rights, social justice as well as green economy related to livestock industry and food system will be examined. The course encourages students to observe and evaluate the impacts of omnivore diet and lifestyle to their personal life, the animals and the planet as a whole.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

• Examine the main concepts related to plant-based lifestyle, such as types of plant-based diet, development and consciousness in Hong Kong, modern livestock industry and global warming, correlation between diet and health in terms of nutrition, Chinese and Western medical science, animal rights of food animals and non-food animals and marketing direction of this movement
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Why we eat pigs but love cats?

2. Does taking public transport help us to reduce carbon footprint?
courses.feedback_evaluation:

2. Internal Course Review

courses.recommended_readings:

Mangels R, Messina V, Messina M, The Dietitian’s Guide to Vegetarian Diets: Issues and Applications, 3rd ed.. Jones & Bartlett Learning, 2011.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Evolution of Universal Communication: Debate and Application
courses.description: This course examines the nature of manner and etiquette systems in the context of interpersonal as well as intercultural communications through exploring its history and development. As part of the social norms, manner and etiquette systems seem to be more universal with increasing socializations in a more globalized world, especially in the business sector. There are still ongoing debates that some countries still preserve their own manner and etiquette systems in some splendid ceremonies and events. This course further studies the factors and socialization processes that shape manner and etiquette system, while specific application will refer to the culture of business in term of practices and behaviours.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

1. Describe the development and the nature of manner and etiquette systems;
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will cover the following topics:

1. History and development of manner and etiquette system
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

2. Internal Course Review

courses.recommended_readings:
1. Bennett, C. (2002). Business etiquette & protocol: Professional development series. Cincinnati, OH: South-Western.

2. Brennan, L. (2003). Business etiquette for the 21st century: What to do – and what not to do. London: Piatkus.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Nature's Classroom: Field Studies of Nature's Genius in Biodiversity
courses.description: This course aims to introduce nature’s genius in the diversity of flora and fauna of Hong Kong and other places. It is specially designed for students in their second year of study or above. The goal is to raise students' awareness of nature’s hidden beauty and genius, including biodiversity and biomimicry. Coursework includes lectures and outings led by experts in their fields, field trip reports, analysis and interpretation of wildlife films in class, feedback on video-clips, a multimedia art exercise, and a biodiversity quiz. Students will learn to appreciate and treasure biodiversity through guided tree walks, bird watching, butterfly photography, and powerful ideas of Nature as our mentor, measure and model in solving human problems. No prior knowledge of biodiversity, or training in multimedia or photography is required, but a sense of wonder, a spirit of inquiry, and passionate curiosity in Nature’s genius.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.component:
Classwork
Discussion
Field Studies/Field-trip
Independent Study
Lecture
Web-enhanced Teaching
Workshop
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:

1. appreciate the importance of learning from nature as their mentor, measure, and model and to apply what they learn to solve real-life problems
courses.course_syllabus:
Major concepts and topics to be covered include:

1. The concept of biodiversity and topics related to Hong Kong as examined by practical field studies

2. Internal Course Review

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Innovation in Service Industry
courses.description: This course provides an understanding of the nature of innovation related to the growth, success and future development of the service industry on the local and global scales. This course aims to provide students with an understanding of how both anticipated and unanticipated changes may influence tourism, hospitality and MICE (i.e. Meeting, Incentive, Convention and Exhibition). The roles of innovation and creativity in responding to change are also emphasized. Consequently, the course addresses aspects of key management problems, needs, developments and approaches that effectively utilize technology and innovation in the service industry. It also encompasses an understanding of various information and other technological methods utilized in the functional areas of development, operations, management, marketing and financial management.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for Hotel and Tourism Management majors or Hospitality and Real Estate majors or students who have taken HTMG1010.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

• Discuss and analyze the key factors responsible for the growth and development of service industry (i.e. in particular, hospitality and tourism industry).
courses.course_syllabus:
The course covers three major sections including hospitality industry, and tourism industry

Section 1: Sprit of Service

Textbook, Mike Peters, Birgit Pikkemaat. Routledge.
courses.recommended_readings: Ja-Shen Chen, Don Kerr, Cindy Yunhsin Chou, Chinhui Ang, (2017) "Business co-creation for service innovation in the hospitality and tourism industry", International Journal of Contemporary Hospitality Management, Vol. 29 Issue: 6, pp.1522-1540.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Experiencing the Kunqu and Peking Opera
courses.description:
Kunqu and Peking Opera are Chinese classical traditions and cultures. The aim of this course is to nurture students' appreciation ability and to deepen their understanding on Kunqu and Peking Opera.

This course serves as a foundation to further study at an advanced level and encourages future participation in Kunqu and Peking Opera performance.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Understanding Globalization
courses.description: This course helps students to understand the major concepts, theories, debates and reflections related to globalization. Particular thematic issues such as economy, environment and sport as well as non-traditional security issues in the fields of humanitarian intervention, terrorism, nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking and global health will be examined. The course encourages students to observe and evaluate the impacts of globalization to their personal life as well as the role of Hong Kong between the East and the West in the era of globalization.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for students who have taken UGEC2514 or UGEC2990/ANTH2520
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

• explain the main concepts such as regionalism, global governance and interdependence which are related to the processes of global economic, social, political integration.
courses.course_syllabus: The course covers 4 major sections: Introduction, theoretical frameworks and empirical cases as well as a flipped classroom in the last 2 lectures.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

2. Internal Course Review

Manfred B. Steger, Chapter 2, “Is Globalization a New Phenomenon?”, pp.17-36.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Food Psychology and Healthy Eating
courses.description: You are what you eat. In modern society, food consumption not only fulfils basic human physiological needs but also greatly impacts people’s fitness and wellbeing. This course helps students to understand the psychological processes and factors underlying their food choice and eating behaviour and acquire knowledge and skills in developing healthy eating habits in college and beyond. Main topics covered in this course include the development of eating behavior, social influences on eating, food choice and consumption behavior, eating disorders and treatments as well as developing healthy eating habits.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for Hotel and Tourism Management majors or Hospitality and Real Estate majors.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

• Understand the main psychological concepts, theories and processes relating to food choice and eating behavior such as classical conditioning, associative learning, mere exposure and priming, social influence and self-regulation
courses.course_syllabus:
The course covers the following main topics:

1. The development of eating behavior: Chapter 5 (Rowland and Splane)

2. Internal Course Review

Rowland, N., & Splane, E. (2014). Psychology of eating. New Jersey: Pearson Education, Inc.

2. Social influences on eating: Chapter 5 (Rowland and Splane) & Chapter 4 (Conner & Armitage)

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: History from Words: Experience the Beauty of Literature
courses.description: This course will give a survey of the development of modern Chinese literature. By reading selected works of major authors, this course investigates the thoughts, the artistry and the significance of modern Chinese short stories, novellas and poems. Besides, it gives a survey of the development of Hong Kong literature by reading the works of major authors. The relationships between literature and history, as well as between literature and society, will be emphasized. The artistic quality of Hong Kong literature and its place in modern Chinese literature will be evaluated.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for students of Department of Chinese Language and Literature.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

1. describe the general contemporary history of China and Hong Kong through reading modern literature
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will cover the following topics of modern literature:

1. Chinese Poetry
courses.feedback_evaluation:

2. Internal Course Review

• 王德威：《想像中國的方法：小說、歷史、敘事》，北京：三聯書店，1998年

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: The Rise of Populism in Europe
courses.description:
This course covers a wide variety of material and is highly relevant in understanding rapid changes in Global and Comparative European Politics. Part I of the course provides a brief historical background to European politics and sets the scene for the course, in examining theoretically how contemporary ‘populism’ is defined and conceptualized in the 21st century political landscape.

Part II of the course provides the main focus of the course, in focusing on the main causes and drivers that have led to the growth of (a) radical right-wing populism and (b) radical left-wing populism. Three key approaches are drawn on in Part II of the course, with comparative studies, survey research (public opinion) and case studies across Western Europe and Central-Eastern Europe allowing students to understand about the diversity and variations of populism in the contemporary political landscape.

Part III of the course introduces students to critical debates and evaluations on the ‘rise’ of populism and just how important understanding this political phenomenon is for (a) the implications for contemporary democracy and governance in EU member states, alongside (b) how populism on the ‘right’ and ‘left’ of the political spectrum is challenging the future EU project. Part III of the course also draws briefly on comparisons between the primary causes of ‘populism’ in the European context, to the causes of ‘localism’ in the Hong Kong context.

The final part of the course also revisits the premise and assumption made in Part I of the course, about the historical stability of the European political landscape by outlining how a shift has taken place, with ‘a new form of politics’ now existing in European politics. Stability and patterns of partisan alignment have now been replaced by instability and widespread patterns of electoral volatility.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for students who have taken GPAD3160.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

• Understand what contemporary ‘populism’ is and the different variants of this political ideology (Populist Radical Right-Wing and Populist Radical Left-Wing Parties)
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1- Introduction to the History of European Politics

Week 2- The Formation of the European Union, the ‘Traditional’ Political Landscape in Europe and ‘A New Form of Politics?’
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

2. Internal Course Review
courses.required_readings:
PART I: THE EUROPEAN POLITICAL LANDSCAPE

Week 1- Introduction to the History of European Politics
courses.recommended_readings:
Due to the rapid ‘rise’ of populism across Europe, there is no current textbook that can account for such systematic changes in European Politics. As a result, this course will utilize a number of interactive online readings/resources alongside latest cutting-edge peer-reviewed journal articles. These online resources are outlined below in more comprehensive detail and supplementary op-ed articles will also be posted to the Course Blackboard page weekly.

ONLINE RESOURCES:

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Hong Kong Myths
courses.description: As an international city, Hong Kong has been praised in world class financial services; one of the most efficient governments in the globe; a vibrant and pluralistic globalized city which can serve as the bridge between China and the West even after the handover in 1997. The above Hong Kong myths are valid to some extent, but very often people in Hong Kong have neglected the successful driving forces behind. More importantly, could Hong Kong’s successful development be sustained in a long run? This is an introductory course on contemporary Hong Kong issues. This course applies an interdisciplinary approach and aims at introducing students to basic concepts from Hong Kong’s economics and trade, to administrative and political system of Hong Kong, as well as the role of Hong Kong in international relations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to

• Understand various driving forces behind Hong Kong myths such as world class financial center, a leading efficient government in the globe and an international city that links up China and the West.
courses.course_syllabus:
Class 1 – Introduction

Class 2 – The Colonial Legacy
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey

2. Internal Course Review

Textbook

Chiu, Stephen Wing Kai and Wong, Siu Lun (editors), Repositioning the Hong Kong Government: Social Foundations and Political Challenges, Hong Kong: Hong Kong University Press, 2012
.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Lo, Shiu Hing, Governing Hong Kong: Legitimacy, Communication and Political Decay, Nova Science Publishers, Inc, 2002.

2. Ma, Ngok, Political Development in Hong Kong: State, Political Society and Civil Society, Hong Kong University Press, 2007.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: The Beauty of Chinese Painting
courses.description: This course introduces the materials and tools, techniques in brushwork, ink tone variations, and colouring to beginning students of Chinese painting. It also focuses on the techniques of painting in an expressive manner i.e. in the literati tradition of “writing the idea”. In this regard, Chinese calligraphy and painting techniques, as well as the forms of expression are covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
2. Not for Fine Arts Majors.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Promotion of Emotional Wellness: Concepts and Practices
courses.description: This course aims to promote students’ awareness and understanding of various issues related to emotional wellness through an online learning platform. The content of the online platform is developed by CLEAR with the collaboration of various teams in CUHK. It covers some common wellness issues encountered by our students, such as perfectionism, anxiety and academic stress.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for Social Work Majors and students who have taken UGED1553, UGED1554, PSYC1020 or PSYC3760.
courses.component:
Independent Study
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course,

1. Students are equipped and prepared when encountering with emotional problems and the ways to ask for emotional support.
2. Students develop a sense of self-discipline on their studies with the hybrid designs of e-learning and face-to-face in-depth discussion.
3. Students master concepts and skills through service-learning group project on promoting mental wellness at college.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Concepts of Emotional Wellness
Study the definition of emotional wellness and the emotional wellness of Hong Kong people.
2. Emotional Wellness Issue: Perfectionism
Discuss the definition, causes, symptoms and effects of perfectionism. Explore strategies in dealing with perfectionism.
3. Emotional Wellness Issue: Anxiety
Discuss the definition, causes, symptoms and effects of anxiety. Explore strategies in dealing with anxiety.
4. Emotional Wellness Issue: Depression
Discuss the definition, causes, symptoms and effects of depresion. Explore strategies in dealing with perfectionism.
5. Emotional Wellness Issue: Academic Stress
Discuss the definition, causes, symptoms and effects of academic stress. Explore strategies in dealing with academic stress.
6. Emotional Wellness Issue: Suicide Prevention
Discuss what factors for suicidal behaviour, and how to identify people having suicidal motives. Explore strategies on suicide prevention.
7. Service-learning project on promoting emotional wellness at College
Based on knowleage and skills acquired, design and conduct a project to enhance students' awareness on emotional wellness.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
Others:

Course and teaching evaluation survey will be conducted in the last week of the course. Students are reminded of their responsibility and right to give feedback to facilitate enhancement of the course. Students are also welcome to give feedbacks to the course instructor at any time in person or through emails.

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Compassionate Communication: Theory and Practice
courses.description: Compassionate communication helps people remain empathetic with ourselves and each other, even in situations fraught with anger or frustration. It helps us to speak to others without blaming and to hear personal criticisms without withering. This approach can be used in nearly any situation — from dealing with troublesome peers in schools to ironing out rough patches with parents at home.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students are able to

1. identify the key concepts of compassionate communication
2. apply the skills of compassionate communication to their daily life
3. develop their pattern of compassionate communication
courses.course_syllabus:
1. How communication affects relationship
Introduce different types of communication and explore the connections between communication, self-awareness and people relationships.
2. Four types of disconnection language
Discuss four types of ineffective communication patterns and identify the disconnection language used by ourselves in daily life.
3. Presence, intention and attention
Practise three key elements of compassion and communication, which are a) presence, b) intention & c) attention, through in-class activities.
4. Needs consciousness, emotions and empathy (empathetic listening)
Discuss how needs have been conceptualized as an account for motivation and as a theory of humanity.
5. Four steps for honest expression
Practise the skills/ steps of compassionate communication, observation, feelings, needs and request through in-class activities.
6. Difficult conversations
Explore effective response to disagreements or conflicts with others, such as a) blaming the others, b) blaming ourselves, c) self-empathy and d) empathising with the others.
7. Conflict resolution
Acquire different skill set to resolve conflicts through demonatration, role-plays and case studies.
8. Basic facilitation for collaboration
Identify roles and types of facilitation, and some easy-to-use facilitation skills to make our work more collaborative.
9. Compassionate communication and social change
Discuss the application of compassionate communication in real-life cases.

courses.required_readings:
1. How communication affects relationship

* Jason Jay and Gabriel Grant, “How We Get Stuck: Breakdowns in Conversation,” in *Breaking Through Gridlock: The Power of Conversation in a Polarized World* (Oakland, CA: Berrett-Koehler Publishers, Inc., 2017),9-28.

1. Four types of disconnection language

* Marshall Rosenberg, “Communication that Blocks Compassion,” in *Nonviolent Communication: A Language of Life*, 3rd Edition (Encinitas, CA: PuddleDancer Press, 2015), 15-24.
* Shantigarbha, “How not to Empathize,” in *I’ll Meet You There: A Practical Guide to Empathy, Mindfulness and Communication* (Cambridge, UK: Windhorse Publications, 2018)),63-74.

1. Presence, intention and attention

* Oren Jay Sofer, “The Power of Mindfulness” and “Relational Awareness,” in *Say What You Mean: A Mindful Approach to Nonviolent Communication* (Boulder, Colorado: Shambhala Publications, 2018), 25-55.

1. Needs consciousness, emotions and empathy (empathetic listening)

* Helen Riess, “Shared Mind Intelligence” and “How Empathy Works,” in *The Empathy Effect: 7 Neuroscience-Based Keys for Transforming the Way We LIVE, LOVE, WORK, and CONNECT across Differences* (Boulder, Colorado: Sounds True, 2018), 9-25.
* Oren Jay Sofer, “Getting Down to What Matters,” in *Say What You Mean: A Mindful Approach to Nonviolent Communication* (Boulder, Colorado: Shambhala Publications, 2018), 111-135

1. Four steps for honest expression

* Miki Kashtan, “Nonviolent Communication as Practice,” in *Spinning Threads of Radical Aliveness: Transcending the Legacy of Separation in Our Individual Lives* (Oakland, CA.: Fearless Heart Publications, 2014), 369-375.

1. Difficult conversations

* Douglas Stone, Bruce Patton and Sheila Heen, “Sort Out the Three Conversations,” in *Difficult Conversations: How to Discuss What Matters Most* (New York: Portfolio Penguin, 2011), 3-20.

1. Conflict resolution

* Simon Fisher, Dekha Ibrahim Abdi, Jawed Ludin, Richard Smith, Steve Williams and Sue Williams, “Understanding Conflict: Towards a Conceptual Framework” and “Tools for Conflict Analysis,” in *Working with Conflict: Skills and Strategies for Action* (New York: Zed Books, 2000), 3-35.

1. Basic facilitation for collaboration

* Miki Kashtan, “Convergent Facilitation General Toolkit,” in *The Highest Common Denominator: Using Convergent Facilitation to Reach Breakthrough Collaborative Decisions* (Oakland, California: Fearless Heart Publications, 2020), 64-106.

1. Compassionate communication and social change

* Marshall Rosenberg, *The Heart of Social Change: How You Can Make a Difference in Your World* (Encinitas, CA: PuddleDancer, 2005).

courses.subject: GEWS
courses.title: Behavioral Science in Everyday Life
courses.description:
Behavioral science is a cross disciplinary approach to understanding the human mind and its decision process. It is a combination of scientific research in social psychology, cognitive psychology, and economics. Behavioral science theories have been used to better understand how humans perceive, think, and make decisions.

The objective of this course is to enhance your understanding of the fundamental factors that drive human behaviors. By understand these factors, you may gain better insights into analyzing your own behaviors and developing strategies for behavioral management. For example, we will teach learning theories (how certain ideas become associated with each other over time; how people learn through conditioning processes) and use these theories to explain behaviors we observe in daily lives [1] [2]. We will also discuss three major theories from the Behavioral Economics literature, including “prospect theory”, “mental accounting”, and “hyperbolic discounting / intertemporal choice”. These theories will help us understand how people value money, why human valuation of money does not simply depend on the nominal value of the money, and how people mentally track expenditures. Students who would like to read about these topics before course registration may consult the following one-page articles: [3], [4], [5]

We will also introduce a simple model that guides behavioral change. We will discuss the EAST framework developed by the Behavioral Insight Team. Although the framework was originally developed for policymakers to guide their policy development, everyone can use the framework to guide their own behaviors. For a quick introduction, see [6]

[1] https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/tech-happy-life/201810/why-do-we-feel-so-compelled-check-our-phones
[2] https://sitn.hms.harvard.edu/flash/2018/dopamine-smartphones-battle-time/
[3] https://www.behavioraleconomics.com/resources/mini-encyclopedia-of-be/prospect-theory/
[4] https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/mentalaccounting.asp
[5] https://thedecisionlab.com/biases/hyperbolic-discounting
[6] https://www.bi.team/publications/east-four-simple-ways-to-apply-behavioural-insights/
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken MKTG3020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students are expected to:

* Gain a deeper understanding of the motivations and behaviors of humans
* Identify what factors shape one’s beliefs and choices in everyday life
* Use theories to diagnose behavioral issues (be able to specify principles and concepts in the diagnosis), and come up with theory-based behavior-change solutions. Apply theories and behavioral insights to promote wellbeing through behavioral changes
courses.course_syllabus:
* Prospect theory - Prospect theory is a Nobel-Prize-winning behavioral model that discusses how people decide between alternatives that involve risk and uncertainty (e.g. % likelihood of gains or losses). It demonstrates that people think in terms of expected [utility](https://www.behavioraleconomics.com/utility/) relative to a [reference point](https://www.behavioraleconomics.com/reference-dependence/) (e.g. current wealth) rather than absolute outcomes. (<https://www.behavioraleconomics.com/resources/mini-encyclopedia-of-be/prospect-theory/>)
* Mental accounting - A behavioral economics concept introduced by Nobel Prize-winning economist Richard Thaler, refers to the set of cognitive operations used by people to organize and track financial activities. Due to people’s limited mental capacity, these operations are often imperfect. Hence, these mental operations often result in biased judgment and decisions. <https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/mentalaccounting.asp>
* Hyperbolic discounting and self-control - Hyperbolic discounting is our inclination to choose immediate rewards over rewards that come later, even if the immediate rewards are actually smaller than the later rewards. The model helps us understand self-control issues from a theoretical perspective (rather than thinking of it as a will-power limitation).
* Associative learning theories - Associative learning theories strive to capture the processes underlying and driving the change in strength of the associations between representations of stimuli that develop as a result of experience of the predictive relationships between those stimuli.[[WMY1]](https://cpi.itsc.cuhk.edu.hk/cpi/secured/dept/dept_cp_mtn_crs.aspx?req_id=n93blw3QbF#_msocom_1) Associative learning is one of the ways people learn to mentally connect things (ideas, concepts) together. The associative learning theories have been broadly used in many different domains, but in this course we will focus our discussion on the role of associative learning theories in habit formation (which will hopefully shed light on how to develop strategies for changing bad habits and building good habits). We adopt the perspective that habits strengthen through associative and award-learning mechanisms that characterize a slow, incremental nature of habit formation. We discuss the theories in class, and contextualize the theories using examples drawn from daily lives.
* System 1 and System 2 thinking - System 1 thinking is a near-instantaneous process; it happens automatically, intuitively, and with little effort. It’s driven by instinct and our experiences. System 2 thinking is slower and requires more effort. It is conscious and logical. Daniel Kahneman suggests that 95% of our behaviors are guided by System 1. By understanding how these two systems work, we will gain better insights into understanding the factors that drive those seemingly “mindless” behaviors.
* Heuristics and Biases in Judgment and decision making - Heuristics are mental shortcuts that can facilitate problem-solving and probability judgments. These strategies are generalizations, or rules-of-thumb, reduce cognitive load, and can be effective for making immediate judgments.
* Design of behavioural change solutions - Students, based on theories covered by this course, design and carry out a service-learning project to help members in their community (College/ family) to change their behaviours so as to promote well-being in the community.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
Others:

Feedback from students will be collected via course-end evaluation. Continuous feedback, comments or questions are encouraged through communications and e-mail exchanges.
courses.required_readings:
* *Books:**

1. Thinking, Fast and Slow, by Daniel Kahneman.
2. Nudge: Improving Decisions About Health, Wealth and Happiness, by Richard H. Thaler and Cass R. Sunstein.

* *Articles:**

Prospect theory

* Kahneman, D., & Tversky, A. (1979). Prospect Theory: An Analysis of Decision under Risk. Econometrica, 47(2), 263-292
* Colin F. Camerer et al. (1997). Labor Supply of New York City Cab Drivers: One Day at a Time. Quarterly Journal of Economics, 112 (2), 407-441.

Mental accounting

Thaler, Richard. (1985). Mental Accounting and Consumer Choice. Marketing Science 4, no. 3 (1985): 199–214.

Time-inconsistent preferences and self-control

* Frederick, Loewenstein and O’Donoghue. (2002). Time Discounting and Time Reference: A Critical Review. Journal of Economic Literature.
* DellaVigna and Malmendier (2006). Pay Not to Go to the Gym. The American Economic Review

Designing self-control solutions

* Ariely, D., & Wertenbroch, K. (2002). Procrastination, Deadlines, and Performance: Self-Control by Precommitment. Psychological Science, 13, 219-224

Associative learning theories

System 1 and System 2 thinking

* Kahneman, D. (2012). Thinking, fast and slow. Penguin.

Heuristics and Biases in Judgment and decision making

Design of behavioural change solutions

* Peters, Kelly (2020). Behavioural Science: The Answer to Innovation? HBR Store. ROT417-PDF-ENG.
* Thaler, R. H., & Sunstein, C. R. (2019). Nudge: Improving decisions about health, wealth, And Happiness. Penguin Books.
* Thaler, R. H., & Benartzi, S. (2004). Save More Tomorrow: Using Behavioral Economics to Increase Employee Saving. Journal of Political Economics, 112, 164–187.
